awd_titl_txt: EXP: Collaborative Research: Empowering Learners to Conduct Experiments
awd_abstract_narration:
This project seeks to transform current practices in the teaching of scientific research methods by shifting the fundamental dynamics and focusing in a scientific domain that is relatable to a broad audience: designing and conducting social and behavioral science experiments. Scientific inquiry is key to making societal progress and improving our understanding of the world. Social and behavioral science programs are largely designed to prepare future researchers, but have a minimum expectation that students become critical consumers of research. Understanding the scientific method and the experimental methods used by researchers is necessary for establishing an ability to effectively assess the research that students will encounter in both the media and scientific outlets. Student understanding of scientific inquiry is significantly enhanced when anchored in inquiry experiences; however, opportunities for scientific research experiences are limited, even in research methods courses, due to the challenges of teaching experimental design and problems regarding access to and recruitment of participants. Without these experiences, students in higher education struggle to fully understand scientific inquiry. To address common barriers to learning how to conduct research, this project is designing a flexible, computer-based platform to be collaborative, narrative-based, engaging, and inspired by constructionist theories to facilitate learning with the use of artificial intelligence (AI) support.
 
The platform developed in this project will serve as a model of a new genre of constructionist research environments, that enable learners to leverage technologies to create, modify, and replicate experiments, recruit participants, and analyze their results to learn about the world. The design-based research approach will operate in two cycles; in each cycle, a revised module and set of tools will be deployed. This results in two major research contributions: (1) Using mixed-methods, the theoretical and educational contribution is to study the process by which students in higher education learn to conduct experimental research, and about the roles of AI assistance, collaboration, narrative, and activities motivated by curiosity, exploration, and reflection. (2) The technological contribution is an innovative, AI-assisted set of scenario creation tools that empower learners to create experiments and that allow us to understand how an intelligent, collaborative, engaging, narrative-based platform can support students in higher education in designing and conducting social and behavioral science experiments.  With this system, it will be easier to create, run, replicate, and build upon studies and to reach out to a broader audience than the pool of university students used in typical in-person laboratory experiments. As a result, the platform will make it possible to transform social science research practices and even has the potential to foster new scientific discoveries.

Overview

This collaborative project between Northeastern University (NU), University of Houston-Clear Lake (UHCL), New York University (NYU), and Worcester Polytechnic Institute (WPI) explored two main research questions:

  1. How can an intelligent, collaborative, playful, narrative-based platform (StudyCrafter) support students in higher education in designing and conducting social and behavioral science experiments?

  2. What can we learn about the process by which students in higher education learn to conduct experimental research, and about the roles of AI assistance, collaboration, narrative, and playfulness?

Using a design-based research approach, we explored these questions by implementing an innovative online platform called StudyCrafter, which empowers students to participate in and create experiments in the form of interactive stories. Players of these experiments take on the role of characters in stories, and make choices that have consequences for how the stories unfold. Data logged on players? choices can be analyzed to answer research questions. We conjectured that this platform would address logistical (accessibility, efficiency), cognitive (understanding, relevance), and affective (anxiety, motivation) barriers in learning experimental research in higher education.

We incorporated StudyCrafter into university-level research methods courses, and studied 6 implementations in two universities (~40 students per implementation). Data collected include pre and posttest responses to surveys we designed to capture students? attitudes and self-competencies with respect to research; and their performance on designing and critiquing research studies. We also collected documents of class discussion forums, and reflection papers written as part of students? course requirements.

Finally, we collected students? StudyCrafter projects, and developed a rubric to rate their designs in terms of their narrative qualities (e.g., story context, player agency, consequential choices), and the robustness of their research designs. 

Intellectual Merit

Findings show that a constructionist narrative-based platform such as StudyCrafter can be effectively implemented in university research methods courses. While there is room for improvement, students were overall positive about the platform, and were able to use the platform to create research studies with little additional guidance beyond what instructors would normally provide to students learning any new research method or tool. 

From a usability standpoint, students? responses indicate that they generally found it time-consuming to learn and use StudyCrafter. Using a visual interface was burdensome for students with prior programming experience, and some students found the lack of flexibility in the authoring tools (e.g., availability of diverse assets), to limit their designs.

At the same time, students expressed a sense of fulfilment over the experience of using StudyCrafter. In their written reflections, students reported thinking more about issues that are broadly relevant to research design, such as the validity of online research data, the implications of research questions posed in a game environment, the purpose of key components of research studies, considerations for recruiting research participants, and strategies for identifying confounding factors. 

We also found evidence that students who attended to certain narrative features of their experiments had more robust experimental designs. However, it will be important for future research to explore the ideal balance between narrative and experimental design. Together, these findings indicate the value of constructionist narrative-based for supporting students? reflection in, and engagement with research design.

Across implementations, we have explored the incorporation of AI support, consisting of automated analyses of the narrative characteristics of students? study designs. In future work, we will explore more usable reports of these analyses, and pedagogical supports to allow students to best take advantage of this available guidance.

Broader Impacts

Findings from this project have been disseminated to international audiences at various refereed conferences across disciplines including the learning sciences, artificial intelligence, and game design. Our work has resulted in a refined online platform for students and instructors to use for research study creation. They have also resulted in tested curriculum materials, assessments, rubrics, and tutorials, which may be used by other instructors and researchers who either wish to use StudyCrafter, or who otherwise wish to engage in similar work.
